repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Environmental Sustainability
            Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Environmental
            Sustainability Development Policy Loan for Mexico were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the adoption of
            environmental sustainability as a cross-cutting priority
            faces many challenges. Maintaining the importance of
            environment as an entity itself, while also mainstreaming
            environmental concerns into all sectors, require delicate
            intervention and coordination between many stakeholders.
            This approach required the adoption of key sustainability
            principles in each sector involved and the selection of
            specific actions contributing to this end. Under
            Mexico's fiscal policy, loans do not increase aggregate
            fiscal resources available to the environment and other
            sectoral agencies since the fiscal envelope is defined by
            the binding primary fiscal surplus targets. This represents
            a limitation to participation since some sectors perceive
            this type of operation as a burden rather than an incentive.
            To ensure that inter-institutional coordination efforts are
            sustained it is essential that an entity take a leading role
            in overseeing these efforts, particularly as participating
            entities undergo an initial learning process and define
            their functions within inter-sector working groups.
            Clearly-defined baseline and target values to monitor
            progress and evaluate outcomes, as well as a relevant set of
            measurable and meaningful outcome indicators, are essential
            for a results driven process.

repnme.cdata!:
World Bank support for Mexico's
            efforts on climate change

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about World
            Bank support for Mexico's efforts on climate change.
            The Development Policy Loan was the first loan of its kind
            for the Bank and the first loan under Mexico’s new Country
            Partnership Strategy, which emphasized climate change and
            had a streamlined structure. It unveiled innovative
            strategies for energy efficiency, power generation,
            transportation, forestry, and land use. Mexico has emerged
            as a global leader in the climate change arena and the
            Development Policy Loan was the first operation of its kind
            for the World Bank. Carbon generation in the Mexican economy
            has been cut by 5 percent since 1993, and more than 100
            projects to cut greenhouse gas emissions, including wind
            energy, urban transport, and waste management, have been
            launched. Mexico ranks twelfth in the world for greenhouse
            gas emissions and second in Latin America after Brazil.
            Climate models developed by various researchers predicted
            that Mexico will suffer disproportionate effects from
            climate change including more frequent floods and drought.
            Climate change was also expected to reduce rainfall levels
            in Mexico. Climate change strategies already have been
            developed under the partnership of Bank. Mexico is a model
            among developed and developing countries on climate change
            and ranks fourth in the world in terms of per capita
            greenhouse gas emission trends in energy, transport,
            residential and industrial sectors, overall greenhouse gas
            emissions and climate policy.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Environmental Sustainability
            Development Policy Loan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Environmental Sustainability
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) supports the Government of
            Mexico's medium-term, outcome-based program to promote
            sustainable development. The overarching objective of the
            DPL operation is to balance socio-economic development with
            environmental protection and improvement. The operation will
            complement actions supported by the recently approved
            climate change DPL and will further pursue the general
            objectives of a previous Environment DPL Program, by
            integrating environmental concerns in the sectoral policies
            and programs of key development sectors: tourism, energy,
            forestry, water, agriculture, and housing as prioritized by
            the government of Mexico (GOM). The original Environment DPL
            Program supported environmental mainstreaming in four of
            these sectors (tourism, energy, forestry, and water); the
            other two (agriculture and housing) have been included at
            the GOM's request. Macroeconomic risks are associated
            with effects on the Mexican economy of: (i) a sharper
            slowdown of the US (and global) economy, decelerating growth
            of non-oil exports and reducing the flow of workers'
            remittances, (ii) higher levels of international commodity
            and food prices leading to further pressures on domestic
            inflation, (iii) increased uncertainty with respect to
            credit conditions for the access of emerging markets to the
            international capital markets, and (iv) declining oil
            production. However, several factors are in place to reduce
            these risks, including: a healthy financial system that has
            begun to expand domestic credit as a share of GDP; more
            dynamism in exports to non-US destinations; favorable terms
            of trade with high oil prices; and the further consolidation
            of prudent macroeconomic policies in both the fiscal and
            monetary realms.

abstracts.cdata!:
This publication is part of a collection
            of five studies conducted by external consultants who were
            attached to various departments of Public Administration and
            Federal Coordination and who were in the Ministry of
            Environment and Natural Resources. The objective was to
            analyze the implications for sustainable development issues
            as diverse as water management, development of financial
            instruments for the sound management of forest resources,
            strategies for development of tourism with sustainability,
            tax incentives for proper utilization of natural resources
            and environmental protection. To meet the social needs of
            the population, to promote the growth of the economy and
            also to incorporate into development policy the
            preservation, protection and rational utilization of
            ecosystems and the environment requires the integration of
            sustainability into public policy building. Faced with
            environmental degradation and destruction and degradation of
            natural resources, the alternative is not extreme
            conservation and implementation of legal constraints.
            Rather, exercise of authority simply is not enough in a
            society characterized by deep inequalities and deprivation
            for large groups of people. Therefore, the federal
            government has promoted the mainstreaming in public policies
            to build a situation which has great impact on natural
            resources and the environment.

            Forestry program 2001-2006 is funding, since the state of
            the national eco-economic area has large challenges
            necessary to seek alternatives for financial resources
            enabling care, conservation and the development of
            commercial forest plantations.

Evaluacion ambiental estrategica del sector
            turismo en Mexico

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objective was to conduct a
            Strategic Environmental Assessment on the Tourism sector to
            consider promotion of policies adopted within institutional
            and legal frameworks. The project also dealt with the
            development of tourism and the potential impacts and the
            manner in which to incorporate the environmental dimension
            in the development model of tourism. The study demonstrated
            that in the last two decades the tourism industry in Mexico
            has grown significantly to become one of the largest in the
            world. This growth is due in large part to the development
            approach infrastructure that has been used, which is
            strictly aligned with market demand within the national and
            international tourist scene.

abstracts.cdata!:
This study aims to review the costs and
            benefits of internalization of externalities through
            environmental and fiscal instruments from the tax
            perspective. It provides an analysis on the impact of the
            adoption of fiscal instruments in environmental public
            finances and the tax system in general. Such requirements
            are analyzed in this study. It tries to provide elements for
            discussion on the impacts of fiscal environmental taxes and
            charges. The study brings international experiences into the
            debate theory for the type of instruments to be used to
            foster recovery and deterioration of ecosystems, and how
            they should be allocated funds from the. The work was
            divided into three chapters. In Chapter I the paper surveyed
            the major environmental projects implemented since the
            public finances, noting the changing context in the country
            and the most significant results that have been achieved. In
            Chapter II, as background to the analysis, the study gives
            an assessment of approaches and experiences in the
            application for special purpose tools of the environmental
            tax, as well as to obtain a double dividend. Finally, in
            Chapter III the paper presents a model to evaluate the main
            impacts of implementation of an environmental tax and the
            application model results that are estimated to levy a tax
            on pesticides, and two variants of taxes on tires. Each
            chapter integrates specific conclusions and finally provides
            a summary of the main benefits of the study.
